Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will enable additional students and postdocs to attend the Seymour Sherman Memorial Conference May 15--17, 2015, at Indiana University, Bloomington. The conference will bring together and promote young researchers at the forefront of different subfields of probability relating to Sherman's work, mainly, statistical physics and probability. Both of these topics are extremely active in the mathematical community and have enjoyed many recent breakthroughs. Therefore ideas and materials resulting from the meeting will be of interest to scientists studying a wide range of mathematical topics.

The majority of participants are recent doctoral graduates, including eight postdoctoral researchers and four assistant professors. Furthermore, two of the speakers are still Ph.D. students. Some of the main impacts of this conference will be on these young researchers, providing them a venue to showcase their work and to interact with others in a range of career stages.

Conference website: http://pages.iu.edu/~rdlyons/sherman/2015.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF conference award was used to partially fund visitor participation for the 2015 Seymour Sherman memorial conference at Indiana University, Bloomington. The conference was in memory of Seymour Sherman, an influential mathematical physicist, and so the topics of the lectures and discussions centered on areas related to his research interests, namely, statistical mechanics and probability theory.

The format of the Sherman conference mirrored that of a similar Sherman conference in 2006, with a keynote lecture given by an established leader in statistical mechanics, Andrea Montanari. This was followed by several lectures given by rising stars in probability, ranging from Ph.D.  students to associate professors. The atmosphere provided by the mathematics department and by the university itself was optimal for young researchers to showcase their work and interact with others at a variety of career stages. These benefits extended to local students and the broader mathematical community through conference participation, attendance, and advertisement.

The conference was a great success, spanning over three days and including fifteen hour-long lectures with several breaks for mathematical discussion.  Speakers were chosen partly for their expository abilities, and many participants commented how much they enjoyed all the talks.  Topics were roughly split into four categories. The first was geometric and percolation problems (critical percolation, connectivity properties of the voter model, isoperimetric inequalities, geometry of log-correlated Gaussian fields, tessellations). Next there were lectures inspired by computer science problems in statistical mechanics (k-satisfaction and bisection problems) and then work on random walk-related models (the frog model on trees, random walk on percolation clusters, and concentration phenomena for covering times of graphs). The remaining lectures were of mathematical physics problems related to analysis (SLE's multi-fractal spectrum, random matrix theory, discrete log gases).
